solar_system.tip: Our solar system has 8 planets that orbit around the Sun. Each planet takes a different amount of time to complete one orbit!
solar_system.about_paragraph_1: The Solar System is the gravitationally bound system of the Sun and the objects that orbit it. It formed about 4.6 billion years ago from the gravitational collapse of a giant interstellar molecular cloud.
solar_system.about_paragraph_2: The Sun is the Solar System's star and by far its most massive component, containing 99.86% of the system's total mass. The Sun's gravity holds the Solar System together, keeping everything from the biggest planets to the smallest particles of debris in its orbit.
solar_system.about_paragraph_3: The Solar System contains 8 planets: 4 terrestrial planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars) in the inner solar system, and 4 gas giants (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune) in the outer solar system. All planets orbit the Sun in the same direction following nearly circular paths.
solar_system.about_paragraph_4: Beyond the planets lies the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, the Kuiper Belt containing Pluto and other dwarf planets, and the distant Oort Cloud, which marks the edge of the Sun's gravitational influence extending nearly halfway to the nearest star.
solar_system.composition_planets: 8 Planets - Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune
solar_system.composition_asteroids: Millions of Asteroids, Comets, and smaller objects

planets.title: Planets
planets.description: Learn about the 8 planets in our solar system

mercury.facts: Closest to the Sun. Has the most extreme temperature differences (-173¬∞C to 427¬∞C). No atmosphere or moons.
mercury.detail: Mercury is the smallest and closest planet to the Sun in our solar system. Its surface is covered with craters similar to Earth's Moon, as it has no atmosphere to protect it from impacts. The temperature varies dramatically - reaching 427¬∞C during the day but dropping to -173¬∞C at night, making it the planet with the most extreme temperature range in the solar system. One day on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days, but a year is only 88 Earth days, meaning Mercury orbits the Sun faster than it rotates!

venus.facts: Hottest planet (462¬∞C). Rotates backwards compared to other planets. Thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide.
venus.detail: Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system despite not being closest to the Sun, due to its thick carbon dioxide atmosphere creating an extreme greenhouse effect that raises surface temperatures to 462¬∞C. Venus is similar in size and mass to Earth, earning it the nickname 'Earth's twin.' Fascinatingly, Venus rotates very slowly and in the opposite direction to most planets (retrograde rotation), causing the Sun to rise in the west and set in the east on Venus. The atmospheric pressure on Venus is 92 times greater than Earth's - equivalent to being 900 meters underwater!

earth.facts: The only planet with life! 71% water. Has 1 moon. Perfect distance from the Sun for liquid water.
earth.detail: Earth is the only planet in the known universe that harbors life. Its surface consists of 71% water and 29% land. Earth has an atmosphere composed of 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen, perfect for life to breathe. Our planet sits in the 'Goldilocks Zone' - the perfect distance from the Sun where temperatures allow liquid water to exist. Earth's magnetic field protects life from dangerous solar radiation. The planet has one large moon that stabilizes Earth's axial tilt and creates ocean tides. Earth is the densest planet in the solar system and the only one not named after a Roman or Greek deity.

mars.facts: The Red Planet. Has 2 small moons. Has the largest volcano in the solar system (Olympus Mons).
mars.detail: Mars, known as the 'Red Planet,' gets its distinctive color from iron oxide (rust) covering its surface. Mars hosts Olympus Mons, a volcano standing 21 kilometers high - the tallest mountain in the solar system, nearly three times the height of Mount Everest! Evidence shows that Mars once had flowing water and a thicker atmosphere, possibly making it habitable billions of years ago. Mars has two small moons named Phobos and Deimos. A day on Mars is remarkably similar to Earth (24.6 hours), but a year lasts 687 Earth days. Mars is currently being explored by rovers searching for signs of ancient microbial life.

jupiter.facts: Gas giant with 79+ moons. Has the Great Red Spot (a giant storm). Could fit 1,300 Earths inside!
jupiter.detail: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system, containing more mass than all other planets combined. This gas giant is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. The Great Red Spot, a massive storm larger than Earth that has been raging for over 350 years, is Jupiter's most famous feature. Jupiter has more than 79 moons, including the four large Galilean moons discovered by Galileo: Io (the most volcanically active body in the solar system), Europa (which may have an ocean beneath its icy surface), Ganymede (the largest moon in the solar system), and Callisto. Jupiter's strong magnetic field is 20,000 times stronger than Earth's.

saturn.facts: Famous for its beautiful rings made of ice and rock. Has 82+ moons. Could float in water!
saturn.detail: Saturn is famous for its spectacular rings, composed of countless pieces of ice and rock ranging from tiny grains to mountain-sized chunks. Saturn is a gas giant with such low density that if there were an ocean large enough, Saturn would actually float! The planet has more than 82 moons, with Titan being the largest - bigger than Mercury and having a thick atmosphere. Saturn's winds can reach speeds of 1,800 kilometers per hour. The rings extend up to 282,000 kilometers from the planet but are surprisingly thin - only about 10 meters thick in some places. Each ring particle orbits Saturn at its own speed.

uranus.facts: Rotates on its side. Coldest planet (-224¬∞C). Has faint rings and 27 moons.
uranus.detail: Uranus is unique because it rotates on its side, with its axis tilted 98 degrees, essentially rolling along its orbital path like a ball. This extreme tilt means its poles take turns facing the Sun, creating seasons lasting 21 years each! Uranus appears blue-green due to methane in its atmosphere. Despite not being farthest from the Sun, Uranus is the coldest planet with temperatures reaching -224¬∞C. The planet has 13 faint rings and 27 known moons. The five largest moons are Miranda, Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon. Uranus was the first planet discovered with a telescope by William Herschel in 1781.

neptune.facts: Farthest from the Sun. Strongest winds in the solar system (2,100 km/h). Beautiful blue color.
neptune.detail: Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun in our solar system, orbiting at a distance of 4.5 billion kilometers. It has a vivid deep blue color caused by methane in its atmosphere. Despite being so far from the Sun, Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system, reaching speeds of 2,100 kilometers per hour - faster than the speed of sound on Earth! Neptune has a Great Dark Spot similar to Jupiter's Great Red Spot, though this storm appears and disappears over time. The planet has 14 known moons, with Triton being the largest and unique for orbiting Neptune in the opposite direction (retrograde orbit). Neptune takes 165 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun!

stars.title: Stars & Galaxies
stars.description: Discover different types of stars and stellar objects
stars.controls: üñ±Ô∏è Click and drag to rotate ‚Ä¢ Scroll to zoom ‚Ä¢ Click a star to highlight
stars.lifecycle_paragraph_1: Stars are born in nebulae - giant clouds of gas and dust. When enough material clumps together, gravity causes it to collapse, creating extreme heat and pressure that ignites nuclear fusion.
stars.lifecycle_paragraph_2: A star spends most of its life fusing hydrogen into helium in its core. Our Sun has been doing this for 4.6 billion years and will continue for another 5 billion years. Stars like the Sun eventually expand into red giants, then shed their outer layers to become white dwarfs.
stars.lifecycle_paragraph_3: Massive stars (more than 8 times the Sun's mass) have shorter but more dramatic lives. They end in spectacular supernova explosions, leaving behind either neutron stars (incredibly dense stellar remnants) or black holes (regions where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape).
stars.question: Question

q1.question: What is our Sun classified as?

q2.question: Where are stars born?
q2.a: In nebulae (clouds of gas and dust)

q3.question: What happens to stars like our Sun at the end of their life?
q3.c: They expand into red giants, then become white dwarfs

q4.question: What is a neutron star?
q4.d: An extremely dense remnant of a massive star after a supernova

q5.question: What powers a star and makes it shine?
q5.b: Nuclear fusion - combining hydrogen into helium

q6.question: What is a black hole?
q6.c: A region where gravity is so strong nothing can escape

q8.question: What determines how a star will end its life?

q9.question: What is a supernova?
q9.d: A massive star explosion at the end of its life

q10.question: What does a white dwarf become over billions of years?
q10.b: A black dwarf (a cooled white dwarf)

sun.name: Sun (Yellow Dwarf)
sun.description: Our Sun is a medium-sized star called a yellow dwarf. It's about 4.6 billion years old and will last another 5 billion years.
sun.characteristics: Temperature: 5,500¬∞C ‚Ä¢ Contains 99.86% of solar system's mass ‚Ä¢ Produces energy through nuclear fusion

red_giant.name: Red Giant
red_giant.description: A large, cool star in its late stage of life. Our Sun will become a red giant in about 5 billion years.
red_giant.characteristics: Very large size ‚Ä¢ Cooler surface (3,000¬∞C) ‚Ä¢ Red/orange color ‚Ä¢ Eventually becomes white dwarf

white_dwarf.name: White Dwarf
white_dwarf.description: The remnant core of a dead star. Very dense - a teaspoon would weigh several tons!
white_dwarf.characteristics: Very small but dense ‚Ä¢ Very hot surface ‚Ä¢ No nuclear fusion ‚Ä¢ Slowly cools over billions of years

neutron_star.name: Neutron Star
neutron_star.description: Created when a massive star explodes. Extremely dense - a sugar cube would weigh as much as all humanity!
neutron_star.characteristics: Extremely dense ‚Ä¢ Rotates very fast ‚Ä¢ Strong magnetic field ‚Ä¢ Only 20 km across

black_hole.name: Black Hole
black_hole.description: The most mysterious object in space! Gravity so strong that not even light can escape.
black_hole.characteristics: Infinite density at center ‚Ä¢ Warps space and time ‚Ä¢ Has event horizon ‚Ä¢ Can't be seen directly

moon_phases.title: Moon Phases
moon_phases.description: Understand the phases of the Moon

new_moon.name: New Moon
new_moon.description: The Moon is between Earth and Sun. We can't see it because the dark side faces us.

waxing_crescent.name: Waxing Crescent
waxing_crescent.description: A thin crescent of the Moon becomes visible. It's getting bigger (waxing).

first_quarter.name: First Quarter
first_quarter.description: Half of the Moon is visible. It's called 'quarter' because the Moon is 1/4 way through its cycle.

waxing_gibbous.name: Waxing Gibbous
waxing_gibbous.description: More than half is visible. Getting closer to full moon.

full_moon.name: Full Moon
full_moon.description: The entire face of the Moon is illuminated. Earth is between the Sun and Moon.

waning_gibbous.name: Waning Gibbous
waning_gibbous.description: More than half is visible but getting smaller (waning).

last_quarter.name: Last Quarter
last_quarter.description: Half of the Moon is visible. The opposite half from first quarter.

waning_crescent.name: Waning Crescent
waning_crescent.description: A thin crescent is visible. Almost back to new moon.

moon_phases.tip: The Moon doesn't produce its own light! It reflects light from the Sun. The phases happen because we see different amounts of the sunlit side.
